case_id: State of Haryana v. Inder Singh (2002) 8 SCC 96
facts: Marriage between Inder Singh (Accused No. 1) and the deceased, Rajbala, took place about one and a half years prior to the incident.
On 24.11.1988, Rajbala died by hanging in her matrimonial home in Village Sisana, District Rohtak, Haryana.
Raj Singh (PW-3), father of the deceased, lodged an FIR (Ex. P-A) on 25.11.1988 at Police Station Kharkhoda.

The FIR alleged that Inder Singh (husband), Rajinder Singh (brother-in-law, Accused No. 2), and Jasbir Singh (father-in-law, Accused No. 3) had been demanding dowry (fridge, scooter, cash) since the marriage.
It was alleged that due to non-fulfillment of demands, Rajbala was harassed and maltreated.
PW-3 stated that about 10-12 days before the incident, his son Satyavir (PW-4) had visited Rajbala, who complained about the continued harassment and demands.
PW-3 and PW-4 testified regarding specific demands and instances of harassment.
Post-mortem examination (report Ex. P-C) conducted by Dr. J.S. Punia (PW-1) concluded the cause of death was asphyxia due to hanging.

The Trial Court (Additional Sessions Judge, Rohtak) convicted all three accused under Sections 304B/34 and 498A/34 IPC, sentencing them to 7 years RI for 304B and 2 years RI + fine for 498A, sentences to run concurrently.
On appeal, the High Court of Punjab and Haryana upheld the convictions.
The High Court, however, reduced the sentence of Rajinder Singh and Jasbir Singh under Section 304B IPC from 7 years to 5 years RI, while maintaining Inder Singh's sentence.
Inder Singh (husband), Rajinder Singh (brother-in-law), and Jasbir Singh (father-in-law) appealed to the Supreme Court.
The Supreme Court noted the death occurred within 7 years of marriage under circumstances raising concerns about dowry harassment.
ipc_sections: Section 498A (Husband or relative of husband of a woman subjecting her to cruelty)
Section 34 (Acts done by several persons in furtherance of common intention)

prosecution_arguments.argument: The death of Rajbala was a dowry death under Section 304B IPC, as it occurred otherwise than under normal circumstances within seven years of marriage, and she was subjected to dowry-related cruelty by the accused soon before her death.
precedents: Shanti v. State of Haryana, (1991) 1 SCC 371 (Defining essentials of S. 304B)
Kans Raj v. State of Punjab, (2000) 5 SCC 207 (Interpretation of 'soon before death')
Gurbachan Singh v. Satpal Singh, (1990) 1 SCC 445 (Presumption under S. 113B Evidence Act)
elements: Death of a woman occurred otherwise than under normal circumstances (hanging).
Death occurred within seven years of marriage (approx. 1.5 years).
Soon before her death, the woman was subjected to cruelty or harassment.
Such cruelty or harassment was by her husband or any relative of her husband.
Such cruelty or harassment was in connection with any demand for dowry.

counter_arguments.loophole: The phrase 'soon before death' requires a proximate and live link between the cruelty and the death, which might be contested if demands were old or sporadic.
supporting_precedents: Sham Lal v. State of Haryana, (1997) 9 SCC 759 (Necessity of proximate link for 'soon before')
Kamesh Panjiyar @ Kamlesh Panjiyar v. State of Bihar, (2005) 2 SCC 388 (Mere past demands insufficient)
Tarsem Singh v. State of Punjab, (2008) 16 SCC 155 (Cruelty must be proximate cause)

counter_arguments.loophole: Testimony of PW-3 (father) and PW-4 (brother) are from interested witnesses and lack independent corroboration.
supporting_precedents: Surinder Kumar v. State of Haryana, (2011) 10 SCC 173 (Caution required for interested witnesses in dowry cases)
M. Narsinga Rao v. State of A.P., (2001) 1 SCC 691 (General principle on corroboration of interested witnesses)
State of Rajasthan v. Hanuman, (2001) 1 SCC 337 (Need for careful scrutiny of relative's testimony)

prosecution_arguments.argument: The accused subjected Rajbala to cruelty as defined under Section 498A IPC, involving harassment linked to unlawful dowry demands, causing mental and physical distress.
precedents: Inder Raj Malik v. Sunita Malik, (1986) Cr LJ 1510 (Delhi HC) (Defining contours of S. 498A)
State of Karnataka v. Dattaraj, (2007) 13 SCC 330 (Nature of proof for S. 498A)
Girdhar Shankar Tawade v. State of Maharashtra, (2002) 5 SCC 177 (Wilful conduct likely to drive suicide falls under cruelty)
elements: The woman was subjected to cruelty.
Cruelty was inflicted by her husband or his relative.
Cruelty consisted of wilful conduct likely to drive her to suicide or cause grave injury/danger to life, limb or health (mental or physical).
Alternatively, cruelty consisted of harassment with a view to coercing her or her relatives to meet unlawful dowry demands.

counter_arguments.loophole: General allegations of harassment without specific instances or dates might not meet the threshold for 'cruelty' under S. 498A.
supporting_precedents: Bhaskar Lal Sharma v. Monica, (2009) 10 SCC 604 (Vague allegations insufficient for S. 498A)
Manju Ram Kalita v. State of Assam, (2009) 13 SCC 330 (Petty quarrels distinguished from cruelty)
Sushil Kumar Sharma v. Union of India, (2005) 6 SCC 281 (Misuse of S. 498A noted, requiring careful scrutiny)

prosecution_arguments.argument: The actions of all three accused (husband, brother-in-law, father-in-law) were done in furtherance of a common intention to harass Rajbala for dowry, making them jointly liable under Section 34 IPC.
precedents: Suresh v. State of U.P., (2001) 3 SCC 673 (Common intention implies pre-arranged plan or prior meeting of minds)
Pandurang v. State of Hyderabad, AIR 1955 SC 216 (Common intention can develop spontaneously)
Mahbub Shah v. Emperor, AIR 1945 PC 118 (Distinction between common intention and similar intention)
elements: Criminal act done by several persons.
Act done in furtherance of the common intention of all.

counter_arguments.loophole: Lack of specific evidence detailing the participation or overt acts of the brother-in-law (Rajinder) and father-in-law (Jasbir) in the cruelty *soon before death*.
supporting_precedents: Dajabhai Chhaganbhai Thakkar v. State of Gujarat, AIR 1964 SC 1563 (Mere presence insufficient for S. 34)
Brathi v. State of Punjab, (1991) 1 SCC 519 (Need for nexus between accused and crime for S. 34)
Krishnan v. State Represented by Inspector of Police, (2003) 7 SCC 56 (Individual acts need assessment for common intention)

defense_arguments.argument: The prosecution failed to establish a proximate and live link between the alleged dowry demands/harassment and the death of Rajbala, a necessary element for 'soon before death' under S. 304B.
edge_cases: Time gap between the last alleged demand (via PW-4, 10-12 days before) and the death.
Whether generalized historical demands satisfy the 'soon before' criteria.
precedents: Banshi Lal v. State of Haryana, (2011) 11 SCC 359 (Emphasis on proximity for S. 304B/113B)
Major Singh v. State of Punjab, (2015) 5 SCC 201 (Reiterating need for proximate link)
Baijnath v. State of M.P., (2017) 1 SCC 101 (Acquittal due to lack of evidence of cruelty 'soon before death')

defense_arguments.argument: The testimonies of PW-3 and PW-4 (father and brother) are unreliable as they are interested witnesses, and their statements contain improvements or lack independent corroboration.
edge_cases: Delay in lodging the FIR (lodged next day) allowing time for deliberation.
Lack of complaints to village elders or authorities prior to death.
precedents: Kali Ram v. State of Himachal Pradesh, (1973) 2 SCC 808 (Burden of proof always on prosecution; interested witness testimony needs caution)
Ganesh Bhavan Patel v. State of Maharashtra, (1978) 4 SCC 371 (Effect of delay in FIR)
Harbeer Singh v. Sheeshpal Singh, (2016) 16 SCC 418 (Need for careful evaluation of testimony of close relatives)

defense_arguments.argument: There is insufficient specific evidence to prove that Rajinder Singh (brother-in-law) and Jasbir Singh (father-in-law) actively participated in cruelty or harassment 'soon before' Rajbala's death, making their conviction under S. 304B/34 and 498A/34 unsustainable.
edge_cases: Liability of relatives living in the same household without specific overt acts attributed to them.
Distinguishing general family friction from targeted dowry harassment by specific individuals.
precedents: Kamesh Panjiyar @ Kamlesh Panjiyar v. State of Bihar, (2005) 2 SCC 388 (Specific evidence needed against each relative)
Preeti Gupta v. State of Jharkhand, (2010) 7 SCC 667 (Tendency to implicate all relatives requires courts to be cautious)
Mahavir Kumar v. State of Bihar, (2014) 13 SCC 588 (Acquittal of relatives due to lack of specific evidence)

judgment.outcome: Appeal partly allowed. Conviction and sentence of Inder Singh (husband) under Sections 304B/34 and 498A/34 IPC upheld. Conviction and sentence of Rajinder Singh (brother-in-law) and Jasbir Singh (father-in-law) set aside; they were acquitted.
reasoning: The death occurred within 1.5 years of marriage by hanging, which is 'otherwise than under normal circumstances'.
Testimonies of PW-3 and PW-4 regarding dowry demands and harassment were found credible regarding the husband, Inder Singh.
The requirement of 'soon before death' under Section 304B was satisfied in relation to Inder Singh, based on PW-4's testimony about Rajbala's complaints 10-12 days prior to her death.
The presumption under Section 113B of the Indian Evidence Act was correctly raised against the husband, Inder Singh, who failed to rebut it.

However, the evidence against Rajinder Singh and Jasbir Singh was found general in nature. There was a lack of specific instances proving their active involvement in cruelty or harassment 'soon before' the death.
The Court emphasized that for conviction, particularly under S. 304B, there must be concrete evidence of cruelty linked to dowry demands by each accused soon before the death.
General allegations against family members without specific attribution of acts close to the time of death were deemed insufficient to uphold the conviction of the brother-in-law and father-in-law.
